subject: RE: [junit] expensive setup which is definitely only required  on	ce
msgSnippet: Create a mock CSVInputStream in setUp that returns exactly the CSV stream you want to test. No need to have a real CSV file on disk. This lets you create a new
messageBody:
Create a mock CSVInputStream in setUp that returns exactly the CSV stream
you want to test. No need to have a real CSV file on disk.

This lets you create a new CSV "file" for every test without the overhead of
disk access.

Terry Wilcox
terry.wilcox@...

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Tung Wai Yip [mailto:tungwaiyip@...]
> Sent: Monday, April 07, 2003 12:23 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] expensive setup which is definitely only required
> once
>
>
> Can you explain why is 1. better?
>
> Let say I want to test some higher granularity methods like
>
> csv.findDuplicates()
> csv.convertToXML()
> csv.calcStatistics()
>
> how would you propose to do it without reading a CSV file?
>
> Wai Yip
>
>
> --- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> > Two things.
> >
> > 1. Think about how to change your design so that your test
> doesn't need to
> > read/write CSV files. This is the better option of the two
> I offer you.
> > 2. If you really can't do (1), then look at TestSetup for
> information about
> > one-time setup.
> >
> > Good luck.
> >
> > So said jakespigl3 on 4/7/2003 --------------------
> > Hi,
> >
> > Being new to junit and the world of unit testing, how do I eliminate
> > part of the setup from being torn down and setup again for
> each test?
> > It seems like a bit of a waste of time.
> >
> > The part of the setup I am talking about is writing a csv
> file for the
> > purposes of getting the class under test to read it. There will be a
> > test case to write a report too - based on the contents of
> the file.
> > There will only be one test case to test the read functionality.
> >
> > How do should I proceed?
> >
> > regards
> > jfc
> >
> >
> >
